metadata.title: Synthesis of poly (styrene-divinylbenzene) by nano-TiO2 and the application for pipette-tip solid-phase extraction of flavonoid in Epipremnum aureum rhizome

sections.text:
ARTICLE HISTORY Received 18 January 2019 Accepted 23 May 2019
KEYWORDS Myricetin; quercetin; nanoTiO2; poly (styrenedivinylbenzene); pipette-tip solid-phase extraction

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
Poly (styrene-divinylbenzene) (PS-DVB) as a common adsorbentmaterial was widely used in sample pretreatment process. As a typical column packing, it had good compatibility with polar organic solvents and sufficientmechanical strength.[1] Titanium oxide (TiO2) nano-material was widely studied in versatile applications[2] ranging from photocatalytic[3] to sewage treatment[4] and solar cells.[5] Comparedwith bulk particles, nano-TiO2 had lager specific surface area, more surface activation sites, and good porosity.[6] For adsorption, its unique structure offered good affinity toward targets, large flow rate, and fast mass transfer.[7] The functionalmonomerwas a key factor affecting the adsorption effect, and the combination of PS-DVB and nano-TiO2 could effectively complement each other’s strengths and weaknesses.[8–10] In order to further improve its adsorption capacity, a variety of composite materials were synthesized by grafting amino onto the surface. Polyethyleneimine (PEI) was a kind of hydrophilic cationic polymer, which can donate electrons and chelatemetal ions molecule.[11] It had been widely used in the modification of supports with micro-grad pores, such as monolith,
membrane, and gelation.[12,13] Moreover, polyaniline (PANI) had a high surface area and faster diffusion rate of the gas. These advantages improved electrical conductivity and environmental stability.[14] They (PEI and PANI) were both amino functional monomers with very good properties, because they could provide hydrogen bond forces with a mass of amine groups.
Myricetin and quercetin were two typical flavonoids, and they were distributed in many kinds of plants, such as Epipremnum aureum rhizome. They hadmultiple pharmacological activities such as antioxidant, antiviral, antimicrobial, antiplatelet, [15] antifibrotic, and anti-inflammatory.[16] These two targets had low levels in plants, and it was necessary to improve the detection method of myricetin and quercetin. Solid-phase extraction (SPE) had been the most frequently used sample preparation technique for trace analysis,[17] and the existing sample treatment methods include molecularly imprinted solid-phase extraction (MIP-SPE), [18,19] ultrasound-assisted extraction (UAE), [20] pipette-tip solid-phase extraction (PT-SPE), and so on.[21–23] PT-SPE was a miniaturized sample pretreatment technique, and it could be used for rapid analysis and detection of trace organic compounds and metal ions.[24–
CONTACT Tao Zhu zhutao@tjut.edu.cn Tianjin Key Laboratory of Organic Solar Cells and Photochemical Conversion, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Tianjin University of Technology, Tianjin 300384, China Color versions of one or more of the figures in the article can be found online at www.tandfonline.com/lsst.
Supplementary material can be accessed here.
© 2019 Taylor & Francis
26] PT-SPE offered the unique and superior combination of shorter operation period and lower consumptions of adsorbent dosage and organic solvent.
In this paper, three polymers including P1 (PS-DVBTiO2), P2 (PS-DVB-TiO2 modified with PEI), and P3 (PSDVB-TiO2 modified with PANI) have been synthesized. These obtained materials were characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM), fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). The specific surface area was tested by Brunauer Emmett Teller (BET) N2 adsorption desorption analysis, and the selective recognition ability was investigated by static adsorption experiments. These obtained materials were applied for PT-SPE of myricetin and quercetin in Epipremnum aureum rhizome. The various factors that affected the extraction efficiency of PT-SPE were optimized, including the influence of washing solvent and elution solvent. Furthermore, the performance of the proposed PS-DVB-TiO2 modified with amino was compared with other kinds of sorbents.

sections.heading: Reagents and materials
sections.text: PS-DVB and nano-TiO2 were purchased from Bona Biology (Jinan, China). N, N-Dimethylformamide (DMF) and PANI were obtained from Shanghai Yien Chemical Technology Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China). PEI was purchased from Alfa Aesar Chemical Co., Ltd. (Tianjin, China). Methylbenzene (PhMe) was from Tianjin Bohua Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. (Tianjin, China). H2O2 was from Concord Technology Co., Ltd. (Tianjin, China). Quercetin and cetyltrimethyl ammonium bromide (CTAB) were obtained from Tianjin Heowns Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. (Tianjin, China). Myricetin was obtained from Shanghai Aladdin Bio-Chem Technology Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China).

sections.heading: Instrumentation and chromatographic conditions
sections.text:
The spectra of the polymers were analyzed by VERTEX70FT-IR (BRUKER OPTICS, Germany) at 4000–400 cm−1, and the morphological microstructures of these materials were observed by FE-SEM (ZEISS, Germany), NETZSCH-F3 TGA (NETZSCH, Germany), and BET (MICROMERITICS, China).
The chromatography system consisted of an LC10ATVP pump and SPD-10AVP UV-vis detector (Shimadzu, Japan) with an injector (20 μL sample loop). The analysis was performed on an Optima Pak C18 column (5 μm, 150 × 4.6 mm, RS tech Corporation, Korea) and Chromatography Data System N2000 (Surwit Technology, China). The mobile phase was MeOH/H2O/acetic acid (50:50:0.003, v/v/v) and the flow rate was set at 1.00 mL/min. The wavelength of the detector was set at 270 nm with injection volume 10.00 μL.

sections.heading: Synthesis of PS-DVB-TIO2
sections.text: The scheme of synthesis is shown in Fig. 1a. Concretely, 0.10 g of nano-TiO2was added to 15.00mLofH2O2 solvent in a 50.00 mL beaker. After 20 min of ultrasound at room temperature, the mixture solution was formed peroxotitanic acid. 0.20 g of PS-DVB and 0.60 g of CTAB were dissolved in 30.00 mL of H2O. Then, the peroxotitanic acid was added dropwise to the suspension solution. The reaction mixture was stirred vigorously in an oil bath at 80◦C for around 48 h under reflux. Then the product was washed thoroughly with deionized water and ethanol. The acquired material was dried at 60◦C for 24 h in vacuum. Finally, the material of PS-DVB-TiO2 was obtained.

sections.heading: Synthesis of amino-modified materials
sections.text:
The synthesis of amino (PEI or PANI) on PS-DVB-TiO2 was performed on the loose polymers as described in
Fig. 1b,c. In details, PS-DVB-TiO2 was added to the 20.00 mL toluene in a 250.00 mL round bottom flask. 1 mL PEI was added in 0.20 g of PS-DVB-TiO2, or the PANI was added in a mass ratio (PS-DVB-TiO2/PANI, 7:1). The reaction solution was heated at 80◦C to reflux for 48 h under mechanical stirring. 20.00 mL DMF as solvent was added with PS-DVB-TiO2 in a 250 mL round bottom flask. The reaction solution was heated at 70◦C to reflux for 48 h under mechanical stirring. And then the resultants were centrifuged in 8000 r/min, and washed by distilled water and ethanol. Finally, the obtainedmaterials were dried at 60◦C for 24 h.

sections.heading: Characterization of polymers
sections.text: Molecular structure characterization of materials was performed by FT-IR spectroscopy. Thermogravimetric analysis was examined experimentally to study the combustion behavior. The samples were heated from 40◦C to 1000◦C in N2 atmosphere. The morphological microstructures of these materials were observed by SEM, and the magnifications were 200 nm. The BET method, also known as nitrogen adsorption, determined the specific surface area and pore size distribution of mesoporous materials.

sections.heading: Preparation of plant samples
sections.text:
The plant samples were prepared according to the next procedure. The Epipremnum aureum rhizome was ground into a fine powder in amortar. 3.00 g Epipremnum aureum rhizome was mixed with 40 mL MeOH in a 100.00 mL beaker. The beaker was fixed on a metal stand and ultrasonic shocked for 30 min. After the leaching step, the residue was filtered with qualitative filter paper. The required Epipremnum aureum rhizome filtrate was taken out and diluted in volume ratio (filtrate:MeOH, 1:1). Then, the Epipremnum aureum rhizome sample spiked at concentration 10.00 μg/mL of myricetin and quercetin was prepared with the diluted filtrate (filtrate: MeOH, 1:1).
Static adsorption capacity of materials
Accurately weighed myricetin and quercetin (10.00 mg) was dissolved in a 50.00 mL centrifuge tube and diluted to the volume of 25.00 mL with methanol. 400.00 μg/ mL of the solution was serially diluted to the concentration of 10.00–400.00 μg/mL with MeOH and to generate calibration standard solutions. For assessing the accuracy, the recoveries of the samples spiked
with targets (1.0, 10.0, 50.0 μg·mL−1) were measured using the established method (n= 3).
In static adsorption test, 10.00 mg PS-DVB, P1, P2, and P3 were placed in a centrifuge tube with stopper containing 1.00 mL MeOH solution (myricetin and quercetin at the concentrations of 10.00, 20.00, 50.00, 100.00, 200.00, 300.00, and 400.00 μg/mL, respectively). The mixtures were mechanically shaken for 10 h at room temperature, and the solution was analyzed by HPLC. The adsorption quantity (Q) was calculated based on the change of the free concentration (Cfree) and the initial concentration (C0) of template by Eq. (1), in which V was the volume of the solution and W was the mass of the PS-DVB, P1, P2, and P3.
Q ¼ C0 Cfree V
W (1)

sections.heading: PT-SPE procedure
sections.text:
In this step, the purpose was to select the best adsorbent, and the materials were tested under PT–SPE conditions. 3.00 mg of different materials including PSDVB, P1, P2, and P3 were placed in separately into the 100.00 μL pipette-tip using degrease cotton at both ends, avoided different materials loss. Next, 1.00 mL pipette-tip was inserted into the smaller tip. And then 1.00 mL spiked sample was loaded into the PT–SPE columns. The eluted solution was collected and dried. The residues were dissolved in 1.00 mL MeOH, and then 10.00 μl of solution was taken for HPLC detection.
The P2 material which showed a best adsorbing ability was selected to further optimize the washing solvent and eluent solvent. In the next step, 1.00 mL MeOH/HOAc (95:5,v/v), diethyl ether/HOAc (95:5, v/v), MeOH/HOAc (85:15,v/v), ethyl acetate, MeOH, ACN/MeOH/HOAc (50:45:5, v/v/v), ACN/HOAc (95:5, v/v), and MeOH/H2O/ HOAc (45:50:5, v/v/v) as a washing solvent was loaded into the PT-SPE device filled with adsorbent, respectively. Then the analyte was eluted with different elution solvent DMSO/HOAc (85:15, v/v), MeOH/phosphoric acid (85:15, v/v), DMSO/phosphoric acid (85:15, v/v), DMSO/H2O/ACN (25:30:45, v/v/v, PH<7), DMF/phosphoric acid (85:15,v/v), MeOH/ACN/HOAc (20:70:10,v/v/ v), MeOH/DMSO/HOAc (40:45:15, v/v/v), and ACN/ DMSO/phosphoric acid (40:45:15, v/v/v) in a centrifuge tube. The washing and eluted solutions were collected and dried. The residues were dissolved in 1.00 mL MeOH, and then 10.00 μl of solution was tested by HPLC.

sections.heading: Characterization of materials
sections.text:
As modification of PEI or PANI could provide more reactive sites, it was important to confirm the adsorption to the target. The SEM images of the PS-DVB and modified PSDVB at same magnifications are shown in Fig. 2. Figure 2a clearly showed that the PS-DVB was a microsphere structure and had a smooth surface with homogeneous micropores. In Fig. 2b, themicrosphere structure of PS-DVBwas destroyed and became irregular shapes, which the surface was combined nano-TiO2. The SEM image in high magnification revealed that the modified PS-DVB possessed a highly porous, the rough, wrinkled, and loose structure. Apparently, these properties increased the interaction between the materials and target, which provided specific surface area favorable for adsorption efficiency. Therefore, the specific structure of modified PS-DVB could provide a better adsorption capacity than PS-DVB.
The BET method could determine the specific surface area of mesoporous materials and pore size distribution. Figure 3 shows the nitrogen adsorption and desorption isotherms for four materials. It is clear to see that the curves are rising uniformly. The starting point of hysteresis loop indicates that the minimum capillary pore began to condense. The end point of
the lagging ring indicates that the maximum hole was filled with condensate. These same phenomena proved that four materials were of the same type of hysteresis loop, in other words, they had the same pore structures. And these materials had columnar pores and narrow pore size distribution. The material aperture distribution curves are shown in Fig. 4. It could be seen intuitively that the sample pore volume density distribution mainly had one peak, which was located around 20–40 nm, indicating that the pores occupied an important proportion in this pore size range. The BJH adsorption average pore diameter of materials were PS-DVB (44.205 Å), P1 (45.807Å), P2 (49.847 Å) and P3 (65.339 Å), respectively. In addition, the average pore size of modified PS-DVB was larger than unmodified PS-DVB. The change of pore size was more conducive to the adsorption of the target on the material.
Figure 5 presents the TGA profiles of the PS-DVB and modified PS-DVB sample weight loss (%) for the temperatures studied from 40◦C to 1000◦C with nitrogen atmospheres, respectively. Nano-TiO2 had high thermal stability, which could improve the thermal stability of PS-DVB. The weight loss of 81.21% of PSDVB, 68.04% of P1, 53.42% of P2, and 79.71% of P3 were showed at 1000◦C in the process. The distinct weight loss between 200◦C and 400◦C was attributed
to the decomposition of stable functional groups on materials sheets. Compared with PS-DVB, the PSDVB-TiO2-PEI had a better thermostability.

sections.heading: Optimization of PT-SPE procedure
sections.text:
Static adsorption capacity of materials Figure 6 shows that the static equilibrium adsorption PS-DVB and modified PS-DVB ascended with an
increase in the initial concentration of the myricetin and quercetin. And the adsorption ability of myricetin, P1 was 9.51 μg/mg, P2 was 28.72 μg/mg, and P3 was 18.17 μg/mg. The adsorption ability of quercetin, P1 was 8.88 μg/mg, P2 was 21.42 μg/mg, and P3 was 18.86 μg/mg. It was clear that PS-DVB which modified had a stronger adsorption effect than PS-DVB without modification. Obviously, P2 had the best effect of adsorption. The consequence demonstrated that PS-
Figure 4. The aperture distribution curves of PS-DVB (a), P1 (b), P2 (c), and P3 (d) at 196 ◦C.
Figure 3. The nitrogen adsorption (solid symbols)–desorption (open symbols) isotherms of PS-DVB (a), P1 (b), P2 (c) and P3 (d) at 196 ◦C.
DVB-TiO2-PEI had a highly porous, rough, wrinkled, and loose structure conducive to the adsorption of the target.
Influence of washing solvents and elution solvents The adsorption rate through PT-SPE is presented in
Fig. 7a. It could be noticed that PS-DVB showed almost a small amount of adsorption to myricetin and quercetin, but the effect of adsorption was significantly improved after modified. P2 showed the best adsorption and was selected to further optimize the washing solvent and eluent solvent, and it was selected for further optimization experiment.
To optimize the optimal washing solvent for the extraction of the myricetin and quercetin, the effect of washing solvent with volume of 1.0 ml was investigated in eight kinds of solvents, including MeOH/HOAc (95:5, v/v), diethyl ether/HOAc (95:5, v/v), MeOH/
HOAc (85:15, v/v), ethyl acetate, MeOH, ACN/ MeOH/HOAc (50:45:5, v/v/v), ACN/HOAc (95:5, v/v) and MeOH/H2O/HOAc (45:50:5, v/v/v) as washing solvent. The efficiencies of these solutions are listed in Fig. 7b. The low loss rate of two targets was achieved by ethyl acetate (respectively, 0.29% and 1.20%), which was selected as optimal washing solvent. And other loss rates of myricetin were 6.15%, 0.64%, 3.80%, 2.01%, 9.17%, 2.27%, and 4.28%, respectively. The other loss rates of quercetin were 29.55%, 9.54%, 18.52%, 12.89%, 26.50%, 21.37%, and 11.50%. Therefore, ethyl acetate was selected for the subsequent process.
The effect of elution solvent on the efficiency was investigated, and the data are shown in Fig. 7c. Different types of elution solvents such as DMSO/ HOAc (85:15, v/v), MeOH/phosphoric acid (85:15, v/ v), DMSO/phosphoric acid (85:15, v/v), DMSO/H2O/
Figure 5. The TGA analysis of PS-DVB (a), P1 (b), P2 (c), and P3 (d) at 80 ◦C to 1000◦C.
ACN (25:30:45, v/v/v, PH<7), DMF/phosphoric acid (85:15, v/v), MeOH/ACN/HOAc (20:70:10, v/v/v), MeOH/DMSO/HOAc (40:45:15, v/v/v), and ACN/ DMSO/phosphoric acid (40:45:15, v/v/v) were investigated (1.00 mL of each elution solvent). As presented in
Fig. 7c, the recoveries of myricetin were 36.09%, 18.83%, 54.47%, 86.39%, 60.45%, 25.47%, 63.87%, and 57.25%. The other recoveries of quercetin were 37.97%, 29.29%, 24.21%, 83.67%, 52.22%, 44.05%, 68.57%, and 48.55%. To sum up, DMSO/H2O/ACN (25:30:45, v/v/v, PH<7) had the best desorption ability and the recoveries were 86.39% and 83.67%. Therefore, 1.00 mL of DMSO/H2O/ACN (25:30:45, v/v/v, PH<7) was selected as the elution solvent for myricetin and quercetin.

sections.heading: Validation of PT-SPE method
sections.text:
The performance of PT-SPE method in extracting myricetin and quercetin from Epipremnum aureum rhizome sample was studied with material P2 under the optimum operating conditions. The LOD (limit of detection) were 0.009 and 0.004 μg/mL for the targets, respectively. The LOQ (limit of quantity) were 0.03 and 0.01 μg/mL for the targets, respectively. The minimum point of the linear range has been corrected to approximately ten times the LOD, so the calibration curve of myricetin and quercetin was constructed in the range of 0.09–200.00 μg/mL. The regression equation of myricetin was Y = 3.00 × 104－3.53 × 104 (R2 = 0.999) (X was concentration; Y was peak area). And the regression equation of quercetin was Y = 2.09 × 104－1.77 × 104 (R2 = 0.998) (X was concentration; Y was peak area). Recoveries of the method were evaluated by performing three replicates of the spiked samples (1.00, 10.00, and 50.00 μg/mL, respectively) on the same day and three different days. As shown in Table 1, the method recoveries of myricetin were in the range of 83.15–97.52% with the RSD (relative standard deviation)<2.11%. And
then the method recoveries of quercetin were in the range of 81.25–93.16% with the RSD<3.91%. The recoveries and the reproducibility of the method were satisfactory for the detection of myricetin and quercetin.
Analysis of myricetin and quercetin in plant spiked sample
In the previous test, P2 showed higher adsorption ability and this result was consistent with the effect of static adsorption. P2 was selected as PT-SPE sorbent to purify myricetin and quercetin (adding standards 10 μg/mL, respectively) from Epipremnum aureum rhizome. Chromatograms of the original sample are shown in Fig. 8a, and the spike method was employed (Fig. 8b). Original Epipremnum aureum rhizome sample with spiked two targets was purified by the developed method with P2. Figure 8c showed that the developed PT-SPE method was reliable with high recoveries.
Comparison with other methods
The comparative data between the proposed method and other methods from literatures are shown in Table S1. The result showed that the developed PT-SPE method had a wide linear range with lower RSDs, and
Figure7. Selection of materials (a), optimization of washing solvents (b) and elution solvents (c) in the PT-SPE process. (a) 1: PS-DVB, 2: P1, 3: P2, and 4: P3. (b)1: MeOH/HOAc (95:5, v/v), 2: diethyl ether/HOAc (95:5,v/v),3: MeOH/HOAc (85:15, v/v), 4: ethyl acetate, 5: MeOH, 6: ACN/MeOH/HOAc (50:45:5, v/v/v), 7: ACN/HOAc (95:5, v/v), and 8: MeOH/H2O/HOAc (45:50:5, v/v/v). (c) 1:DMSO/HOAc (85:15, v/ v), 2:MeOH/phosphoric acid (85:15, v/v), 3:DMSO/phosphoric acid (85:15, v/v), 4:DMSO/H2O/ACN (25:30:45, v/v/v, PH<7), 5:DMF/phosphoric acid (85:15, v/v), 6:MeOH/ACN/HOAc (20:70:10, v/v/v), 7:MeOH/DMSO/HOAc (40:45:15, v/v/v), and 8:ACN/DMSO/phosphoric acid (40:45:15, v/ v/v).
good recoveries were obtained with small amount use of sorbents. It indicated that the proposed method was suitable for the determination of trace amounts of myricetin and quercetin in Epipremnum aureum rhizome sample.

sections.heading: Conclusion
sections.text:
The present paper introduced three kinds of polymer synthesis, as well as a simple and rapid method coupled with PT–SPE technique that was developed to quantify trace levels of myricetin and quercetin in Epipremnum aureum rhizome sample. The obtained polymers were characterized by FT-IR, SEM, TGA, and BET. And P2 material (PEI modified PS-DVB-TiO2) showed good aperture structures with a high specific surface area. Moreover, the static absorption curves showed that P2 had better adsorption ability on two targets. With the optimization of PT-SPE procedure, the method recoveries of myricetin and quercetin were in the range of 83.15–97.52% and 81.25–93.16% with RSDs less than 2.11% and 3.91%, respectively. The LOD and LOQ were 0.009 and0.03 μg/mL for the myricetin. The LOD and LOQ were 0.004 and 0.01 μg/mL for the quercetin. In summary, PT-SPE showed good performance for purification of two targets in Epipremnum aureum rhizome with P2 as adsorbent. The result indicated that the PSDVB after modification exhibited better aperture structures, high mechanical strength, and special selectivity
to the targets, and it might be able to provide a new choice for processing of complex sample.

sections.heading: Funding
sections.text: This work was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China [21808173];Basic Science Research Program through the National Research Foundation of Korea (NRF) [NRF-2019R1A2C1010032];National Training Programs of Innovation and Entrepreneurship for Undergraduates of China [No. 201710060018]; andTraining Project of Innovation Team of Colleges and Universities in Tianjin [TD13-5020].

metadata.abstractText: PS-DVB-TiO2 modifying with amino (polyethyleneimine or polyaniline) were synthesized, and they were characterized by scanning electron microscopy, fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, thermogravimetric analysis, and Brunauer Emmett Teller. The obtained polymers were used for purification of myricetin and quercetin from Epipremnum aureum rhizome by pipette-tip solid-phase extraction. The satisfactory extraction recoveries for the two targets (myricetin 86.39% and quercetin 83.67%) were obtained by changing different washing and eluted solvents. The result showed that the obtained modified PS-DVB exhibited high mechanical strength and special selectivity to the targets, and the proposed method was successfully applied for purifying complex samples with PT-SPE. Abbreviation: PS-DVB: poly (styrene-divinylbenzene); PEI: polyethyleneimine; PANI: polyaniline; SPE: solid-phase extraction; MIP-SPE: molecularly imprinted solid-phase extraction; UAE: ultrasound-assisted extraction; MSPD: molecularly imprinted-matrix solid phase dispersion; PT-SPE: Pipette-tip solid-phase extraction; DMF: N, N-Dimethylformamide; SEM: scanning electron microscopy; TGA: thermogravimetric analysis; FT-IR: fourier transform infrared spectroscopy; BET: Brunauer Emmett Teller. ARTICLE HISTORY Received 18 January 2019 Accepted 23 May 2019
